bioghist.p: John W. Claghorn was a merchant and auctioneer in Boston, Massachusetts, and Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He was associated with the Boston firm of William Prentiss & Son, circa 1814; and with the Philadelphia firms of Jennings, Thomas Grill & Co.; Jennings and Thomas (all before 1835); and Myers and Claghorn, 1836-1840. His wife was Elizabeth Crumby of Boston. John Reed and Standish Forde were Philadelphia merchants.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of business records, largely from the firm of Reed and Forde. Materials include: account books (1789-1808); daybooks (1793-1803); sales books (1784-1805); marine insurance policies issued to Reed and Forde; two Reed and Forde letterbooks, 1791-1793, 1795-1796: an "Outfits" volume, recording financial records of voyages financed by the firm (1786-1806); evidence book related to claims against the Spanish and French, 1790s; and an extract from the minutes of the Insurance Co. of North America regarding election of officers, 1822. The collection also includes correspondence to James L. Claghorn (1817-1884), related to paintings, prints, and engravings. One letter from Thomas Crumby discusses the sale of a portrait of Washington by Stuart.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
